key_title: Key to the species of Hyalosperma

Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Asteraceae

source.author: Short, P.S.
source.title: Hyalosperma
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Short, P.S. (1999). Hyalosperma. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Inner involucral bracts with radiating white or yellow laminae more than 2 mm long; corolla 5-lobed
Inner involucral bracts without radiating laminae or the laminae less than 1 mm long; corolla 3–4-lobed

Inner involucral bracts yellow; outer bracts obtuse or rounded, colourless or brownish; the outer bracts and basal, non-coloured parts of inner bracts c. erect at anthesis (the capitulum c. cup-shaped)
Inner involucral bracts usually white (rarely yellow); outer bracts acute, smaller than but otherwise resembling inner bracts; all bracts widely spreading at anthesis (the capitulum c. hemispherical)
Pappus bristles plumose in the upper half, and dilated toward base and variably united into a sheath; cypsela smooth or minutely papillose; expanded capitula more than 15 mm diam.
Pappus bristles plumose throughout, not or hardly dilated, united only at base; cypsela strongly papillose; expanded capitula mostly up to 13 mm diam.
Leaves terete, not fleshy; entire plant sparsely hairy
Leaves elliptic to obovate, fleshy; entire plant manifestly hairy
